Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Advancing Environmental Sustainability through Innovative Design and Operation of Digital Manufacturing Equipment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512217 (Sutherland). The overarching objective of this research is to generate knowledge needed to establish a new framework for the design and operation of digital manufacturing equipment for increased resource/energy efficiency and enhanced environmental sustainability. Research will be conducted in the following four thrusts: 1) Machine-level energy flow characterization, analysis, and optimization; 2) Energy conscious production planning and control on a digitalized shop floor; 3). Retrofitting and remanufacturing of Computer Numerical Controlled (CNC) machines; and 4) Sustainable design of CNC machines. The research will be jointly pursued by a highly qualified team consisting of researchers from both China and the United States. Professor Sutherland from Purdue University, a pioneer in the area of sustainable manufacturing, will lead the U.S. part of the team. Professor Shao from Huazhong University of Science and Technology, a renowned expert in digital manufacturing, will lead the Chinese part of the team in partnership with Harbin Institute of Technology and Hefei University of Technology. The team members expertise complements perfectly with each other to pursue seamless integration of sustainable manufacturing and digital manufacturing. Working together it is expected that the knowledge and technologies generated in this project will be disseminated to industry in a very timely manner. The data/information enabled sustainable manufacturing approach to be developed will enhance productivity, efficiency, and sustainability, a key for both the China and U.S. machine tool industries and their respective manufacturing sectors.

This research represents one of the first efforts to take advantage of the emerging digital manufacturing paradigm with the goal of advancing environmental sustainability. The project will enhance understanding of resource and energy flows over the entire life cycle of digital manufacturing equipment, from design, manufacture, operation, maintenance, to remanufacturing, which in turn offers insight into the design and operation of this equipment for improved environmental performance. In particular, characterizing and modeling energy flows at both the machine and shop floor levels make it possible to develop dynamic scheduling procedures for better energy and power efficiency when facing uncertainties and within smart grid scenarios. Data mining-enabled automated LCA could lead to a completely new and highly efficient approach for conducting LCA on complicated products. This project will significantly improve the resource and energy efficiency of digital manufacturing equipment over its entire life cycle. This, in turn, will lead to significant cost saving and carbon emission reduction. In addition, the research findings will be infused into multiple courses within the industrial, mechanical, and environmental and ecological engineering curricula at Purdue, as well as corresponding schools/departments in partnering Chinese universities. These activities will increase the amount of sustainability-related educational materials in these curricula. During this project, the PIs will continue their efforts to recruit students from under-represented groups into engineering. Students working on this project will be encouraged to share their experiences via social media to generate interests in conducting research among their peers. By communicating with their counterparts in the other country, students are also expected to gain exposure to a different culture. To reach an even broader audience, all the findings, case studies, and teaching materials will be made available on manufacturingHUB.org.

This grant is co-funded by the Global Venture Fund (GVF) of NSF's International Science and Engineering section (ISE), the CMMI Manufacturing Machines and Equipment program, and the CBET/ENG Environmental Sustainability program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to advance environmental sustainability of manufacturing equipment. The project improved the understanding of resource and energy flow throughout the life of manufacturing equipment from design to remanufacturing. This project has impacted the environmental footprint of manufacturing through research on machine tools, a commonly used type of manufacturing equipment. Machine tools are used in manufacturing to shape material into desired products, and since they also consume significant amounts of energy, they have a large environmental impact. The objective of this project was to generate knowledge that would reduce the environmental impact of machine tools throughout their entire lifecycle: design, manufacturing, use, and end-of-life. This project has generated knowledge to improve the design of machine tools, inform how they are used, and improve the remanufacturing of the machines at their so-called end of life.

The first outcome of this project is the methods/tools that have been developed to improve the design of machine tools. This project researched methods to incorporate sustainability into undergraduate mechanical engineering courses that will help future designers to include sustainability as an objective in their designs. This will impact machine design but also the design of engineering systems. This project also provided new tools to designers to improve sustainable product design. These included visual tools that provide feedback regarding environmental implications of their designs. In addition, the project explored methods to design machine tools with a smaller environmental impact. These methods included reducing the machine tool?s mass. Similar to how a lighter weight car will consume less fuel, a lighter weight machine tool may use less electricity.

The second outcome of this project is the improvement of how machine tools are used. This project explored the scheduling of jobs and use of machine tools powered with renewable energy. Since renewable energy sources do not have consistent energy output, e.g., solar panels provide no power at night, manufacturing schedules would have to be planned to run jobs when renewable energy is available. This project explored the use of a wind turbine, solar panels, and battery storage at a factory to reduce the amount and cost of electricity from the grid. The research explored changing operation schedules (demand-side scheduling) based on the availability of renewable energy while maintaining the predetermined throughput. The project also modeled energy consumption during manufacturing of products to better understand how process parameters impact energy consumption. This research serves to reduce manufacturing energy consumption while meeting traditional production requirements. 

The third outcome of this project is the improvement of machine tool remanufacturing at product end-of-life (perhaps more appropriately termed end-of-use since the life of the product and its components/materials does not end) through advances in disassembly. Disassembly is an important step in the process of remanufacturing and recycling of machine tools and other products since improved disassembly makes it easier to recover and repair components of the machines. This project improved disassembly through increasing efficiency by balancing the work across disassembly lines. Balancing of disassembly lines distributes the work across the different lines to increase the speed of the disassembly line. This project also researched disassembly planning to decrease the time it takes to disassemble large products. Previous research focused on sequential disassembly that takes a long time with large products. This research introduced cooperative disassembly to decrease disassembly time.
